bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John A. Owen, Jr., December 11, 1947

div1.p: Hench requests copies of the photograph of Hench, Jordan, and Darden that was taken at Hench's recent speech at the University of Virginia. He suggests to Owen that the Alpha Omega Alpha society consider making Kean, Cooke, and Moran honorary members.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John A. Owen, Jr., December 11, 1947
div1.opener:
December 11, 1947
Mr. John A. Owen, Jr.
President, Virginia Alpha Chapter
University of Virginia, Department of Medicine
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Mr. Owen:
div1.p:
I have just returned from a busy Eastern trip. I enjoyed my brief
visit to Charlottesville. By separate post I am sending you a reprint which
might interest you.

If it isn't too much trouble or expense, would you kindly send me
four of the photographs which were taken of you, Dan Jordan, President Darden
and me? I should like to keep one and send the others to the relatives of
Walter Reed.

Two or three days after I left Charlottesville, Mrs. Hench and I
had dinner at the home of Walter Reed's son General and Mrs. Walter Lawrence
Reed in Washington, and a day later, enroute to Mercersburg, Pennsylvania,
we visited Walter Reed's widow and daughter, now living at Blue Ridge Summit,
Pennsylvania. Mrs. Walter Reed is 92 years old. They were interested to
hear of my visit to Charlottesville.

May I repeat in this letter the suggestion that I made to you casually
by word of mouth - that your fraternity, Alpha Omega Alpha, could honor itself
by honoring the three University of Virginia men who were so closely associated
with Walter Reed; namely, General Jefferson Randolph Kean (incidentally the
oldest living decendent of Thomas Jefferson), Dr. Robert P. Cooke, of Lexing-
ton, Virginia and Mr. John J. Moran of Havana. I do hope that you will not
think my suggestion presumptuous but I believe that honorary memberships in
Alpha Omega Alpha for these three men are worth considering. General Kean
and Doctor Cooke of course became physicians and General Kean was one of the
great physicians of the Army. Johnny Moran only took one year at the medical
school at the University of Virginia when his funds ran out, but he had already
made a contribution to the human race, the likes of which few graduates have the
opportunity to make.

I realize that others of your chapter may not consider this suggestion
appropriate, therefore, I do not expect any reply, as I don't want to embarrass
anybody by my suggestion.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
